alternatives.transcript: well the tobacco Institute is calling on parents to discourage their kids from smoking and it now has an ad they say will do just that

they're going through only looks different from what you went through and there's a lot you can share with them so before your kids make important decisions like smoking talk to them help them decide not to smoke everybody needs help talking to their kids sometimes call for your free booklet on how parents can talk to their teenagers about smoking and other tough issues the family course Consortium belief smoking shouldn't be a part of growing up

about 150 television stations around the country that we know of I suspect others that we don't know of it's the first time we've ever done public service announcements but it's an outgrowth of a very aggressive campaign that we began in about 1985 if you're saying the kids should not smoke because it's bad for them then can't you make the next logical step in that thought process that it's bad for adults to you've never made that that that point at all well

what we're trying to do is differentiate between what's an acceptable choice for adults to make and what isn't acceptable for kids as a society we make a lot of judgments about what kids are and aren't ready for either by law or by social custom can serve in the military they can't get credit they can't get married they can't drink alcoholic beverages they can't smoke because they're not ready to make a lot of those decisions and they get pressured into them by their by their friends let me just go one step further though we see advertising out there

and the Peanuts characters advertised Metropolitan Life Insurance kids can recognize a lot of advertising logos and figures but that doesn't mean that they're allowed or should or want to buy those products if that were the case then we'd see I think a tremendous increase in kids smoking and that hasn't been the case friend what's your position on all this well once again we see the tobacco industry in sheep's clothing they have a product that kills over 400,000 people

a year and yet they want us to honestly believe that they don't want someone to use this product if you look at the campaign side by side this public relations campaign helping youth decide is about a 10 million dollar a Year campaign it looks at the legal ramifications it's an adult Behavior you can't buy the product till you're 18 or older it does not talk about health at all in its campaign now put this side by side with something like the Joe Camel ad
